block.p: In "Forget PCB's. Radon. Alar." (Sept. 11), Gregg Easterbrook focuses much needed attention on those in some developing countries who breathe air and drink water hundreds of times poorer in quality than any in the industrialized world. And he is right on target when he identifies population growth as the driving engine of environmental degradation, and improved maternal and child health as key factors in slowing that growth.

But I do not agree, as Easterbrook implies, with his dismissal of environmental hazards in industrialized nations and of changes in the global environment like global warming as "minor ecological problems."

In "Forget PCB's. Radon. Alar." (Sept. 11), Gregg Easterbrook focuses much needed attention on those in some developing countries who breathe air and drink water hundreds of times poorer in quality than any in the industrialized world. And he is right on target when he identifies population growth as the driving engine of environmental degradation, and improved maternal and child health as key factors in slowing that growth.

But I do not agree, as Easterbrook implies, with his dismissal of environmental hazards in industrialized nations and of changes in the global environment like global warming as "minor ecological problems."

The most disturbing aspect of his thesis is his failure to comprehend the dimensions of the human crisis we face in coming decades, unless we halt our rapidly escalating degradation of the global environment.

We formed the Project on Global Environment Change and Health to promote a wider understanding of the medical consequences of global environment degradation. ERIC CHIVIAN, M.D. Harvard Medical School Boston
